html:
centuriō (a centurion)

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /kenˈtu.ri.oː/, [kɛn̪ˈt̪ʊ.ri.oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /t͡ʃenˈtu.ri.o/, [t͡ʃɛn̪ˈt̪uː.ri.ɔ]
  • Audio (Classical)
    		(file)

Etymology 1[edit]

From centuria (“division consisting of one hundred”) +‎ -ō.

Verb[edit]

centuriō (present infinitive centuriāre, perfect active centuriāvī, supine centuriātum); first conjugation

  2. I divide into groups of one hundred.
  3. (military) I arrange into companies.
  4. (only in perfect participle) having voted according to centuries.

Derived terms[edit]
  • centuriātiō
  • centuriātus
Related terms[edit]
  • centum

  • centuriātim

Etymology 2[edit]

From centuriō +‎ -ō.

Alternative forms[edit]

  • centuriōnus

Noun[edit]

centuriō m (genitive centuriōnis); third declension

  2. centurion; commander of a hundred men
Declension[edit]

Third-declension noun.

Case Singular Plural
Nominative centuriō centuriōnēs
Genitive centuriōnis centuriōnum
Dative centuriōnī centuriōnibus
Accusative centuriōnem centuriōnēs
Ablative centuriōne centuriōnibus
Vocative centuriō centuriōnēs
Derived terms[edit]
  • centuriōnātus
Descendants[edit]

(all borrowed)

  • Catalan: centurió
  • Czech: centurio
  • English: centurion
  • French: centurion
  • German: Zenturio
  • Italian: centurione
  • Portuguese: centurião
  • Romanian: centurion
  • Russian: центурио́н (centurión)
  • Serbo-Croatian: centurion
  • Spanish: centurión
